column11: Review Text

column8: Mystery yet to unravel much of its past.
column11: Still hiding much of its history Buduruwagala makes an impression from the start if the drive towards the ancient temple ,winding through the forest and waters with the traveler being the solitaire due to its serene secrecy tucked away from the beaten paths of typical  tourist..

We actually saw a photo of this place in the Buddha Museum in Kandy. And it was well worth going. The setting is lovely with a small lake nearby and mature gardens surrounding the area.  The paths to the Buddhas are nicely groomed and well looked after by the ladies tending the area. When you get to the Buddha, only then do you realise how massive it is.  Our driver said it's 15-20m and we didn't believe him.  It is 57ft which is about what he predicted! It is a very small area but it was a beautiful one to visit.
buduruwagala is nice place which you can visit on the way from ella to down south or udawalawa, very calm environment you can relax your mind...

column8: Wonderful, magical place that is often overlooked
column11: the gigantic Buddhas of Budurvagala carved into the rock are definitely worth the detour on the way to or from Ella. The driveway there alone is very beautiful in the countryside, past a lake embedded in a great rocky landscape. In Budurvala itself, you rarely meet tourists, which is another reason to visit the place. The Buddhas are simply sensationally impressive
I'm not a connoisseur but this sculpted rock wall is really beautiful and imposing. The site is well worth a visit.

column8: Good trip to Visit ancient Wellawaya
column11: Amazing nature. It look like we are driving in the jungle. some birds , peacock, wild buffalos, monkeys , so many butterflies. Very ancient place. Feels like you are staring at alive giant rock.

column8: Worth a quick trip to see these massive Buddhas carved into the rock over a thousand years ago
column11: Worth a visit for scenery leading up to rock carvings on its own . Large carvings of Buddha carved out of the rock dating back to 7-9 century AD. Do stop in at Sam‚Äôs cafe if you are craving decent coffee in Sri Lanka . Proper Italian coffee sitting in idyllic surroundings . Not horrible Nescaf√© here !

Beautiful ancient Buddhist temple of the 10th century carved in rock. There are seven statues the gigantic central of about 15 meters and represented by Buddha while on the sides we find the family .. including a female figure the consort Tara and children .. The thing that anchors me is the enchanted place ... the thin clean and crisp air that enters the nostrils the peace and tranquility ... far from everything you find outside this almost heavenly corner .... suitable for those who practice meditation ...ü§≤

Beautiful, peaceful location. Amazing temple. With nice little cafes near the entrance. The site has monkeys, and you need to remove your shoes to go onto the actual temple area,  lovely location to sit under a tree.
Incredible sight - this is a very special place that I would strongly recommend. Beautiful drive there, and the Buddha‚Äôs themselves are simple mind blowing

Enjoyed this temple out in middle of nowhere. Very peaceful. Interesting and thought though there is not much to see, glad we visited here. Lovely little cafe place where they serve great fruit drinks with the furniture looking like it came from The Hobbit!
This is a truly beautiful monument, but what stands out most is the powerful message behind it. Our guide, Roshan, conveyed this in an amazing way.
It is a temple absolutely worth visiting for its beauty but above all for its importance. Try to read something before you go so you will fully appreciate its beauty.

Incredible. If you can get here early morning or late afternoon it would be even more amazing. Plan to sit under the big tree and take in the bird song and ambience of this serene place. Plan to have a meal or some refreshments at Sam's Cafe.
This place was amazing and was the cheapest attraction we went to.  I would thoroughly recommend this.  No crowds either!

Visited the Buduruwagala temple, it was a very hot day and although you don't go inside you still have to cover your legs and shoulders up. It's literally just a large stone temple . It was still worth the visit even though it was a short one

Sometimes you come to places and wonder why they aren't much busier and more popular. The Buduruwagala is a beautiful old Buddhist temple where nine statues were originally carved into a large rock, of which about seven are still clearly visible. Impressive from a distance as a whole, but also up close in size and detail. Warm under your feet again, because here too the rule is: take off your shoes.
Not that much. Little bit of history and art. Not bad at all l. Thefe was a boat ride in the lake. And also wde can witness the aquaduct being built
In the middle of nature is this wonderful temple, some fantastic figures sculpted into the rock wall... Amazing and beautiful and a must-see...

If you have your own transport, Buduruwagala Temple is well worth a visit.  Located between Ella and Tissamaharama.  Drive about 15 minutes or so on a small road that takes you alongside pretty, tranquil lakes, marshes, and waterways with great birdlife. The statues are impressive, and the environment absolutely peaceful and lovely.  Very few tourists. Nice!
Wonderful! I have never seen anything like that! A very beautiful and energetic place! I definitely recommend going! the visit will not take much time!

This ancient Buddhist shrine cut out of the rock face with the imposing Figure of Lord Buddha and his consort Tara in smaller relief along with other statues is a gem hidden from usual tourist attraction. However the place has a huge positive vibration if one is lucky to stand under the imposing Buddha
Not too much to see so we didn‚Äôt stay long but it was very impressive and felt like a sacred place. I‚Äôm glad we saw it. A huge Buddha carved into the rock from a long time ago.

Researching for our trip I had found this site just 5km off the main road from Ella to Udawalawe and Yala so was it worth a stop on the way, it seemed no to most considering the few Western people reviewing. Which always gives cause to stop. And well worth the short trip oit was. Just 406 (yes ban odd number) rupees to enter, 200 metre walk takes you to the single scene of a 25 metre high standing Buddha carved into the rockface with three smaller figures on each side. Quite a sight and more so considering it was done was basic tools estimated to be over 1200 years ago. One smaller figure has a white stucco finish which it is thought may have been common to all but has eroded with time on the other figures. A quiet serene atmosphere in woodland, wonderful short visit. There are other small broken stupas around the site.
One of the oldest temples I have ever seen in Sri Lanka. And that stone carving art is so beautiful and amazing.
This is an ancient temple with rock caving in wallawaya. It is beautiful  location and have a quiet environment. This temple is well worth to visit.

It‚Äôs all about the amazing things created centuries ago and we are fortunate to see it. Lot about our history. Mr Sujeewa Attanayake who is in below picture will explain in English and Sinhalese languages about the history.
I am glad I visited place. Drive to this place is very nice through the lake and wilderness. Has a quiet a history behind this too.

We came here while on the way from Ella to Yala National Park (for afternoon safari tour). It was a pleasant surprise hidden gem off the beaten path where the road leading to this temple would pass by beautiful lake. Upon reaching the ticket booth where we paid LKR364 individually for entry. Another short drive of 5-10 mins to reach the entrance where ticket will be validated and appropriate dress code is required. They offer cloth to cover up if your short/ dress is above the knee. A short walk along the path (5-10 mins) leading to the impressive rock carvings. In Sinhalese, Budu means Buddha; ruwa means image; and gala means giant rock. Hence, Buduruwagala literally means Buddha image on giant rock. Buddhism rock carvings was originally from India where the cultural influence can be seen in other parts of the world such as China, etc. We have seen the similar heritage, namely  Longmen Grottoes with Giant Buddha carvings in Luoyang, China where is larger in scale and size. However, we still love this place for its authenticity and the mysterious atmosphere when walking through the paths and the woods to discover the beauty of this cultural heritage, built since 10th century. Totally love it!!!
Marvelous ancient rock carvings of Buddhas located in beautiful surroundings. The place is quiet , not many turists, and we got a sense of sancturary beeing there.

Seven statues sculptured on relief of the rock are seen in a single rock face. Of the seven Mahayana statues, three smaller statues each are sculptured on either side of the main Buddha statue. The centrally sculptured main Buddha image is the tallest in Sri Lanka and is 51feet in height. The Buddha is in the Samabhanga posture and has the right hand gesturing¬† the Abhaya Mudra. On the right of the Standing Buddha image are the sculptures of Avalokiteshvara Bodhisatva, Goddess Tara,¬† Prince Sudhana and on the left are the sculptures of Maitree Bodhisatva, Vajrapani Bodhisatva and an unidentifiable deity. These sculptures could be identified as a collection of the Buddha and Bodhisatva figures with Mahayana influence.

This site was not particularly busy which was a pleasant change from many Buddhist sites. There are seven rock cut statues of which only the center one is the Buddha. Dating is uncertain but they may have been made in the 10th c AD. Some orange on the Buddha indicate the statues may have been painted. The place name means 'the rock of Buddhist sculptures'. The Buddha statue is 16m/51' high, the tallest Buddha statue in Sri Lanka. You have to remove your shoes to go on the platform.

Our driver didn‚Äôt seem to think this was worth the 5km detour but we‚Äôre so glad we didn‚Äôt listen and requested to view it anyway! And we were definitely glad we continued in the car once past the ticket booth instead of trying to walk as some brave souls were doing in the heat and humidity of the midday sun to the ticket check point The statue of Buddha carved into the rock is stunning! It stands 15mtrs, lonely planet states it being the tallest on the island! You won‚Äôt be sorry for the detour...

We were driving from Udawalawe to Yala and this was en route, so we asked to stop. Its a drive from the main road, but I think that's part of the experience. The area is very quiet, and we saw a massive water monitor crossing the road (the only one in our whole trip). The statues are interesting, one being the largest in SL, and over 1000 years old (I think) and have similarities to the now lost statues at Bamiyan; excavation work is still going on, so it looks like there's more to be uncovered still from this ancient site

Dropped in on way to Ella out in no mans land very impressive , just the one site to visit , only do it if close by don‚Äôt think it would be worth spending hours to drive to nice eating spot just at entrance both together nice

Ancient rock carvings of Buddha. This historic attraction is location off 15 minute drive from the mail road. The access road is not that great but it routes via a village with nice surroundings. Worth spending time for this trip on your way to Wellawaya.

This temple is well worth stopping. It‚Äôs impressive. We paid 354 rupees ($2.00) entry fee. There weren‚Äôt many tourists. The negative is the rough and narrow road to get there.  It's tight when two cars pass each other going the opposite direction.  On our way out, a tour bus was arriving.  About 5 cars had to back out to find an area wide enough for us to pass the bus.  It was tight.
A silent and serene place with beautiful statue of Buddha, carved out in the solid rocks. 2100 years old. The lake is close by and also a beautiful view. It's really worth a trip!

The guide books suggest that Buduruwagala is a site not much visited by tourists and to some degree this was on my visit a reasonable description. However it is worth travelling to if you have a few days either in Ella or going past on your way to Yala. There were a few tourists visiting while I was there but you really had the place to yourself. Apart from the rock Buddha carvings it does provide a chance to sit back and take in the surroundings and simply relax. The surrounds are well maintained and provide plenty of shade to escape from the sun. Cost is 354Rps and is about an hours drive from Ella.

On the way to Yala we made a short visit here. Adult ticket price costs LKR354/- which goes towards preserving heritage places like this one. As it was a religious public holiday, many worshipers were visiting the place too. It was a good short visit, the place exudes calmness. When walking towards the area, you could see the giant carved Buddha statue it was a sight to behold. There are rules when taking pictures, be sure not to face your back towards the statue.
A quiet and peaceful place to visit. The old carvings in the rock are well worth a look. There is a charge for foreigners.
Fascinated to see unfamous creations of Sri Lankan heritage. Definite visit if you‚Äôre touring Moneragala. Just on the way to Arugam Bay. Will never regret the visit.
This is one of the most beautiful, scenic, rock carving ancient temple in wellawaya . A must visit for any tourist.

This used to be a village with this rock temple as a center. It is of the beaten track site. Try also to eat a wood apple from one of the stalls on the side of the road to this site. Entrance fee is Rs362. He statues are nicely carved out of the rock. I found also on the right side in the rock some carving. Our driver translated it as ‚Äúsnake rock‚Äù, that there must be a lot of snakes back in the days.
Off the road,but worth the trip.  These beautiful statues cut in the rock in a lovely green area are really surprising but most important peaceful.

A bit off the beaten track and a small walk through the bushland is Buduruwagala Temple. It is a temple like no other we have seen. A huge rock with carved statues, 7 in all, the centrepiece is Buddha.

Stopped here on the way to Ella.  Tourist books suggested this was off the tourist route which I wouldn't entirely agree with, there were a number.  The rock sculptures were very impressive but I actually enjoyed clambering up adjoining rocks and enjoying the view through the trees.  A really tranquil and beautiful spot.

This place was so tranquil and I loved how it was not completely overrun with tourists. The rock carvings are an absolutely beautiful sight and completely worth it if you are in the area, and I would say even if it is within an hour‚Äôs detour. You don't need to walk through or enter a temple to see the rock carvings, so conservative dressing is not necessary and shorts are okay. There are hardly any steps to climb, and a decent amount of shading provided by nearby trees, so don't worry about coming here while the sun is shining bright.

Buduruwagala is an ancient Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka. The complex consist of seven statues and the statues date back to the 10th century. All the statues are done in a granite rock. Nice peaceful place to visit.

As it's a bit off the beaten track, and not many tourists visit there, it's extremely peaceful, and you are likely to be there with just few others. It makes it an incredible experience, even a little bit spiritual (for someone who is not at all!), the scale, the beauty, the quietness, it's incredible!

Whilst in Ella my wife and I (both 27) hired a scooter to visit Diyaluma Falls and Buduruwagala. The drive down was stunning with great views over the mountains and then the fields lower down. The carved rock face at Buduruwagala is fascinating in its size, detail and age. It is the tallest standing  Buddha carving in Sri Lanka. You can get very close and it is quite quiet. However before you go do be aware that it is a single rock face and it not very big. So limit your expectations. I would recommend it, my wife was less impressed. If you combine with Diyaluma or are passing by then I recommend visiting, but don't go just for this (unless you are staying in Wellawaya).

Our driver was on a long dusty road in a residential area flanked by houses with tables and plates/bowls of wood apples for several minutes before reaching the entrance where we purchased our tickets. We passed some ruins, several peacocks, a few small lakes and some narrow paths that can fit only one car. There was a small restaurant near the parking area for the rock sculptures but it was closed at the time (we arrived after 3:00 pm on a weekday).  Aside from the guard, we were the only visitors to the site. The path towards the sculptures is uneven, but not many steps.  As we approached the sculptures, we could hear many birds in the trees chirping. To walk up the few steps, you must remove your shoes.  Only two of us did, the others admired the sculptures from below. One of the unique features of these sculptures is that some of them appear to be stepping away from the rock behind.  Take a look at the feet which appear to be stepping on to the pedestal. These sculptures date back to the 10th century.  The tallest is 51 feet high.  There is nothing shiny or gleaming with gold, only ancient carvings and sculptures that have existed for over 1000 years - wow.
we weren't expecting the scale or beauty of this carving. Take time on the car journey from the entrance to stop at then lakes to admire the abundant wildlife

An ancient buddhist temple in Sri Lanka. The complex consists of seven statues (10th century).The largest of the standing Buddha statues is 51 feet from head to toe; is the largest standing Buddha statue of the island. Entry fee 1US$ (SAARC)

Of the many temples we visited during our tour, this was probably the one I like better. The ruins are located in a relatively quiet area and the entrance to the site is 2 U$ (or the equivalent in local currency, of which we had none left). After a short car ride from the entrance, you approach the ruins located close to very picturesque marshes. Walking up a sort of corridor, you reach impressively carved rocks: the central Buddha statue is 16 m., the largest in Sri Lanka. Two groups of thee people are carved at each side of the central Buddha. One painted in white with an orange halo is particularly eye-catching. There isn't much apart from the huge sculptures and the stairs leading to them, but it is very impressive. This is supposed to be the second oldest temple in Sri Lanka, dating back to the 10th century, but it is still used by worshippers, therefore one must wear appropriate clothes and remove shoes to approach the statues, as in any other temple. Most recommended.
This place is full of history. Very beautiful environment. Very natural and ancient. Relaxing and enjoying. We really enjoyed ourselves here. The rock statues were magnificent.
Very charming place. Good history to learn with. A bit sad though that the office there did not have a comprehensive manual about the place. Anyway, a must go see site. very educating.
This is unbelievable in a jungle area to see this kind of ancient statues ,Nice calm place to visit if you visit Udawalawa region.some interesting lakes on the way. Amazing old rock carvings.

This is very worth to see. This is unbelievable in a jungle area to see this kind of ancient statues in a big rock. Any one can easy to go when you go to Udawalawa, Yala or other area of south coast in Sri Lanka from famous Ella town

It's a lovely trip along a quiet road to the rock carvings which are very impressive. Fortunately we were the only ones there (apart from the ubiquitous monkeys) so we could enjoy the site in peace and quiet. En-route to the rock carvings there's a picturesque lake.
This very small site has not been preserved but is worth stopping at if passing by. I would not make a detour to visit it.

In the summer of 2018 we (Dutch familie of 4, kids 13 and 18) travelled to discover the beauties of Sri Lanka. We arrived after a long day travelling on bumpynroad from Ella, Liptons seat and Diyaluma falls, but it proved zen ending of the day. After paying 322 roepies per person instead of the mentioned 200 (the driver said most government prices are rising recently, petrol from 90 to 118/liter), but the wide area is nice and neat and the open air temple was astonishing! We were alone with the huge granit half-statues and had all the time to study them. When we left a busload of monks in purple and orange robes arrived.

There are temples galore in Sri Lanka, but this is not the one that has been reviewed by others here where there is a colorful Buddha and colorful Buddhist drawings.¬† That one is much closer to Ella and can be easily confused as there too there is a similar large carving into a rock face. Here at Buduruwagala Temple there is an idyllic drive from the main road through farm land and rice paddy fields.¬† There is an idyllic walk up a well kept path which opens up to the carvings in the rock face.¬† They are a sight to behold but unfortunately without knowing the history of them they do not capture your attention to a great length of time.¬† The wildlife (lizards) enroute we found more fascinating and the drive in and out to this temple.

Situated amidst the woods, this is a Dina place to visit if you are a history lover or a has a passion towards arts and crafts. Dated back to centuries, Buduruwagala depicts the religious influences as well. However, not to forget is the narrow roads that lead to Buduruwagala, which you may find difficult to go by a big vehicle, such as a bus.

Beautiful n simple temple. There are beautiful paintings inside the small temple. Natural n old paintings. Some of them are newly painted too. Outside the temple is n massive buddha statue carved in the mountain rock. Big n beautiful sculpture carved in the mountain. We missed it at first then saw it into the mountain wall. Beautiful peaceful temple.

A few kms off the Wellawaya to Tanamalwila highway by Buduruwagala junction, this place is a hidden gem of 7-8 century rock carvings with the central image of Buddha. Incredibly spiritual and peaceful surrounded by jungle where apparently there are more ancient sites but are not accessible. An amazing natural stone bath which fed from an underground spring. A well spent hour an a chance to see crocodiles in the lake and maybe the odd cobra on the approach road. (Best not to walk this bit!)

On our way from Bandarawela to Yala we drove off the main road to this Temple.  Beautiful statues carved in the rock.  They almost make one think of the detroyed statues in Afghanistan. Easy walk from the parking to the actual Temple site.  There were not many people at the time of our visit which gave us the time to walk around and snap photos.

Very impressive thousand year old rock carvings set in peaceful gardens a few miles from Wellawaya. Well worth the short diversion of the main road to take a look. Clouds of butterflies line the short walk to the carvings. Relatively undiscovered by tourists yet. The nearby juice bar is worth a visit if thirsty.

Stopped there on our way from Ella to Yala. Sacred place and so silent. Felt like one was surounded by monks and spirits from when it was built. Remember to have knees and shoulder covered. Or else there is free sarongs.
On the way to YALA turn next to wellawaya and drive about 5 km. That's a amesing carving in a jungle.
This is a Very Important location to visit when you are in Bandarawela. this place has so many stories behind. Highly recommend this place, but NEED a guide or GOOGLE about the History

It was a bit of a hike over rough ground to get to the temple but well worth the walk. There was only our group when we visited so it was nice to walk around without it being crowded. There no toilets so s bush stop was the only way out of that situation!
one of the best temple in the area this was my 2nd time road was  ok  , place was well worth the visit peace full place

The place was quite tough to access, as the road that leads to this place is so much of roughness from the main road. But the place was well worth the visit and this builds up so much of spirituality and proud if you are Buddhist. Not recommend to travel this place during the mid day time as the stones gets very hard to step on.

Definitely a must see on the way to Tissamaharama. Although it doesn't take much time to see the carvings, the lakes on the way to the carvings are superb for bird watching. We saw an eagle resting on the ground and gasped in awe at its beauty when it took off. At another lake the reflection of its shoreline boulders made for a serene picture so stunning.
Is are very good place and beautiful temple this man is very good sri lanka is most beautiful I love sri lanaka

This was a highlight! Ancient, majestic statues in the middle of nowhere - and no sight of any other tourist. The road to get there is bumpy, but short, and the walk from the car park is only 200m or so.

Huge rock with 7 statues.  This is located between Wellawaya , Kuda Oya. The road bit bad for rainy days because of mud. Entrance ticket costs Rs 500/= . No toilets though we pay for that. Must be develop. For the back packers could take a tuk tuk from the junction at the main road. Cheers !!
These are Buddhist Mahayana style carvings in a serene place, no big tourist busses...25 min away from the main road.

Peaceful setting surrounded by a small nature reserve with lots of bird life and a small lake.  Carvings were very beautiful and if you manage some time there without other tourists it is very rewarding.

This place has a stillness about it - or maybe we were lucky with very few visitors the day we went. Regardless, the sculptures here are amazing in scale & presence. A little off the beaten track but easy to get to. Astonishing when contemplating the scaffolds that must have been in place to complete this work.

There is a little hike through lovely countryside to get to see these amazing rock carvings. The central Buddha stands 15 metres high and is the tallest in Sri Lanka. The statues have been in existence for a thousand years and weathered very well. It was great to find no crowds and a feeling of being in a peaceful religious place.

This shows the history of Sri Lanka. Mahayana Buddhism is representing in here. Giant 7 statues were sculptured in a rock. All embedded within rock. Nice calm place to visit if you visit Udawalawa region.

7 massive statues carved out of solid rock. its located on the way from Ella to Tissamaharama main road and drive 5 km into the complex. very peaceful environment for meditation. its not much crowded attraction as other part of the country....

This temple is well worth a visit when traveling on the Wellawaya road. It is helpful to have transportation because the temple is not on the main road. The path to get there is very interesting because you get to see quite a bit of wildlife like birds, varrans. We drove all the way to the statue, but ambitious travelers can trek all the way too. The Buddha statues depict both Mahayana and Theravada manifestations of the Buddha. It is a very peaceful location to have a temple and the statues carved in rock have a very natural look. We enjoyed the temple as well as the bird life in the area.

Seven massive rock cut figures - from 10th C - amazing. The gigantic Buddha statue may have been once brightly painted as still bears a long streak of orange on the robe.  The site is both an archaeological site and temple so shoes off. To get there from the main road we drove a few km down a tiny road by most beautiful rivers, lakes, swamps - would have loved to walk it given more time...

We stopped off here on our way from Ella to Tissamaharama (Yala). It's about 20 mins of the main road but passes some interesting lakes on the way. The site itself consists of large cliff face that has 6 or 7 huge states carved into it. Buddha takes centre stage and either side he is flanked by other Hindu/Buddhist states. The carvings themselves are well preserved and are huge. When we were there (August) it was not busy at all, there were only a few westerners and a group of local buddhists who sat on the grass nearby chanting which added a beautifully peaceful atmosphere. Glad we made the detour!

I think the cashier took too much money from us - 300 rupees for one ticket... and about five minutes there. One big Buddha and four, five small, that is all. Good business for tuk tuks and for cashiers.

We didn't know quite what to expect when our driver suggested a short stopover here on the way from Ella to Hambantota. We arrived around 3pm as a bus of pilgrims from Kelaniya temple were leaving. We practically had the whole place to ourselves. The setting itself is beautiful. The drive there passes by lakes teeming with birds and lotus flowers. Upon arrival we were asked to pay an entrance fee 500lkr per person (children were exempted). The receipt show that it's actually a donation to the upkeep of the temple, which we are happy to contribute towards. After walking through a pathway with trees on both sides, the view opens up to the carved statues on the rock wall. We are not religious people but the whole experience was very moving and spiritual. We couldn't stay too long as we wanted to get to Hambantota before it got too late. It's a peaceful place to be at and we would highly recommend a stopover here if you are in the area.

The Buduruwagala Temple Buddha rock carvings are really spectacular to see. The giant Buddha and then small carvings next to it are amazing. Unfortunately the carvings are not protected from rain so parts of the rocks are starting to break off. Very quiet peaceful spot.

Amazing old rock carvings. Hard to get to so you need to have your own transport. Thee is public transport up to the site but it's quite a distance from the main road Museum junction to he site and public transport is definitely not the way to get there. The larger tourist coaches have trouble going down the road and they have to stay near the museum. Plenty of Tuk Tuks and a tuk tuk ride to the site rather than taking the car down the rugged road makes it more interesting. Agree on the rate up and down beforehand. A monk has an illegal ticket counter at the entrance to the site and charges entry fees. The site is not his and he does not represent the Department of Archaeology which owns the site. Discuss this too with the Tuk Tuk drivers. They are also unhappy about the illegal business of this rogue monk. If the monk gets difficult report to the Tourist Police unit on +94112421451 or to the regional police on  0552277316
This was absolutely wonderful- we were almost alone at the temple surrounded by sounds of nature. Our guide was knowledgable not only on the site, but on the local flora and fauna as well.
Off the road, this place deserve a visit. The trip from main road to the temple goes through beautiful countryside and wildlife. The site is very peaceful and the rock carvings are stunning!

Off the beaten track road through the lovely countryside and small village to happen upon this ancient site. Prior to going in on you will pass an ancient Buddist archway on the left where a new Buddist Monastery is being built. It's a short walk through the the woods where there was lots of small white butterflies fluttering. We followed the ancient low steps until we turned a corner. There in the near distance you first glimpse the size of the statues of an ancient King, his wife and welcoming people. As you get nearer it truly is special and hopefully you will get a sense or appreciation for how it came to be so long ago without today's modern machinery. It's a serene place, only a handful of tourists on our visit. Last month in the rainy season it was difficult to access this site due to the roads to get to it which are unmade (our guide reassured us that the villagers in rainy season are fine). You can spend as little or as long here depending on your interests, Its a peaceful place to sit. There is a bench under a large tree with a view towards the rock.

Buduruwagala is situated in the Wellawaya District Secretariat Division of the Moneragala District. It could be reached by traveling 4 km along the road opposite the Buduruwagala School which is about 4km from Wellawaya on the Ella & Wellawaya  road. Seven statues sculptured on relief of the rock during the 10th Century  A.D. are seen in a single rock face. Of the seven Mahayana statues, three smaller statues each are sculptured on either side of the main Buddha statue.

Amazing little spot off the obvious track (thankfully our driver took us, most local tuktuk drivers also know where it is). 300RS entry and we used a local guide to tell us the history of the statues and carvings - the tallest Buddha image remaining in the country and a well looked after area. The space is taken care of by a family who have been doing so for 3 generations, very knowledgeable and well worth utilising their guidance (we tipped 300RS and had one of the family for half an hour give us the full history of the images, the area, and even the animals that lives nearby!)

Buduruwagala ‚Äì ‚ÄúRock of Buddha Statue‚Äù was a monastery complex belongs to Mahayana School of Buddhism which established in the south-eastern regain of the island in 9-10th century AD. The only remaining from old temple is this massive Buddha statue carved in to the natural rock and height is around 16 meters. There are two sets of Bodhisattva groups of Avalokitesvara and Vajrapani. All these stature were covered with a plaster and panted at the beginning. Still there are some colours remaining on the rock. It is 4 kilo meters away from the Wallavaya ‚Äì Thissamaharama Road (A2). This is worth to visit destination in Sri Lanka. You can come from Ella to Wallavaya and then head toward this awesome place.

There are 07 great ancient figures carved on a massive rock with 51 foot Buddha's image. Very peaceful countryside with nice lake can be experienced while you are driving along the road to the temple. If you are passing Wellawaya area do not miss this site in Uva province, Sri Lanka.

Sure that there is nothing much to see but this temple also shows the ancient carvings and sculpture with precision when mankind did not have sophisticated technology like today. A very good place to be relaxed. Wild elephants can be around but should be safe during daytime to visit.

These are ancient rock carvings of Buddha figures in a peaceful and natural setting, a few kilometres up a rough road which passes through some stunning natural scenery where we saw kingfishers and water monitor. Not at all commercialised and so much the nicer for it - we are glad we went.

Access to the site is by a long unmade road - the journey is well worth it as the scenery, flora, birds and the wildlife in the ponds around the area are as much an attraction as the temple itself I thought the rock carvings have survived in remarkable condition bearing in mind their age Definitely worth a detour to visit if in this part of Sri Lanka

When I first saw a picture of these carvings in Kandy Buddhism Museum, I took a note that I want to visit Buduruwagala Temple. And after I did visit it, I wasn't disappointed. The carvings are huge and really impressive. Even though it's just a group of seven figures, they gave me a better feeling of something ancient and great, as Anadhaputra, and only slightly less so than Polonnaruwa. Look around for dragonflies and lizards if you like nature, and find lots of photo opportunities by the lakes on the way to/from the site.
OK, it is 1,000 years old but it is not exactly spectacular. Not much time to be spent there. I am a bit generous with my 4 dots.
Amazing remnant from a thousand years ago.  Worth the 300 rupees per person.  No need for a guide though one will ask you when you buy your ticket.

05km's away from Wellavaya-Tissa main road. On the way to the site you will be passing one of the best sceneries of Sri lanka. Paddy cultivation, Lake and dam, Natural jungle etc. From the car park 05 minnnutes walk to the site. It's not advisable to visit during raining period. Road getting muddy and water level of the lake will comes to spil level. Statues are cut from the natural rock and nobody knows exactly when it done. Normal belief is 10th Century. Related to Mahayaana Buddhism.

Buduruwagala is absolutely worth to see. 7 Buddhish statues from the 10th century hidden away from the normal tourist route. Our driver recommended this and it is fantastic. The guide at the entrance is very well knowing and very proud of this historic site - which is to understand. We are all alone in a fantastic scenery with white butterflies and a nice walk to this temple. Presently no tourist crowds which is also nice an peaceful in a historic place.

Buduruwagala is a historic place of interest, lying 3-4 kilometers from the main A2 road that leads to Wellawaya. Accessing this place is pretty easy either using public or own transport. The narrow road that leads up there from the main road may be difficult to motor during rainy seasons (my experience was a few months back; may be the road is in better shape now). The main attraction of the site are the Buddha statues carved into a solid rock. Those carvings are nearly 1000 or more years older according to the findings. There a several statues facing different directions. The site is calm and peaceful which encourages visitors to stay there longer. If you are traveling around Wellawaya and have some time to spare, this is a place to visit.

Seven gigantic Buddhist statue dating back to the 10th century some of which still bears traces of the original stuccoed robe. Absolutely worth seeing. Rs 300 in entrance fee. Direction: 3 km on the main road south of Wellawaya (busses), then 4 km on a small road to the temple. If you have 2 hours: walk one of the ways. The road goes through a bird sanctuary with lots of waterbirds and butterflies, as well as paddyfields. Very quiet. Where the road from the city meet the little road is a Buddhist museum (with a few Hindu statues as well). Absolutely worth seeing. Free entrance. However, none of the signs are in English.

I can only assume it is the relative remoteness of this place and the lack of publicity that prevents it being more popular. I only asked to go there because I saw a photo of the site at Rawana Falls. The road to the site is narrow, twisty and absolutely fascinating going past fields and lakes. There is a nominal entrance fee by a car park area. From there it is a short walk through trees to the temple site. It is basically a rock face surrounded by trees; the face itself has a series of huge, carved images of Buddha in relief. I understand one is the largest such on Sri Lanka being 16m tall. The exact interpretation of them is not fully understood but some are believed to be of future Buddhas. In any event they are simply beautiful and in such a peaceful setting far different in atmosphere to the more famous and busy sites elsewhere. It is well worth spending some time to get here and look around.

There are only assumptions of this rock carving. It is stated that this carving was in the 9th - 10th Century. The carvings have been stopped abruptly & not completed. The ceiling to protect the carving has not been completed. It is not known which King commissioned this carving. The surroundings are very beautiful & a very clean place. It is away from the hustle & bustle of town life. The boards make it easy to locate. The temple assistants are very helpful & accept donations. There is no entry ticket. I recommend visiting this place by 06.30 am if you need to take good photographs as the sun sets behind the rock in the evening & optimum results are not possible.
The atmosphere of the place is very nice. To reach the site you drive thru paddy fields and some lakes with interesting wildlife. A short walk of 300 meters will bring you to the statues.
